name: SPIRE
description: The SPIFFE Runtime Environment
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/master/LICENSE>.

floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
warnings_strict_justification: The project is strict with warnings and requires that pull requests emit no Linter warnings.
static_analysis_justification: No FLOSS tools available for Go.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: No Floss tools available for golang.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The code is not written in a memory-unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The code does not include run-time assertions.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The project's default security mechanisms do not depend on weak algorithms or modes.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: The project tries to use hardening mechanisms whenever possible and favor  "secure by default". https://github.com/spiffe/spire/blob/master/MAINTAINERS.md#security-and-usability
crypto_used_network_justification: The project supports TLS for all of its network communications.
crypto_tls12_justification: The project supports at TLS version 1.2, as provided by golang.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: The project performs TLS certificate verification by default.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: The project performs certificate verification, and before sending HTTP headers, but it does not need to send private information.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
documentation_current_justification: Docs are generated with every release. https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe.io
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The project's specification and runtime implementation are fairly accessible as-is.
internationalization_justification: the software doesn't generate text intended for end-users and doesn't sort human-readable text
sites_password_security_justification: The project site does not store passwords.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: No FLOSS tools available for golang
build_standard_variables_justification: No native binaries are being generated by the project.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The project does not restrict the user of relevant flags.
build_non_recursive_justification: The project does not recursively build subdirectories. All of its dependencies are external to its installation.
external_dependencies_justification:
SPIRE has the following build-time dependencies: golang (BSD 3-clause), go.uuid (MIT), golang/protobuf (BSD 3-clause), logrus (MIT), go-grpc (Apache 2.0), go-plugin (MPL-2.0), hcl (MPL-2.0), gorm (MIT), gopsutil (BSD 3-clause), go-hclog (MIT), grpc-gateway (BSD 3-clause, Apache 2.0), inflection (MIT), go-bindata (CC0 1.0), go-sqlite3 (MIT), sqlite (public domain).
As a golang project, SPIRE has no special runtime dependencies.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: The project does not rely on externally-maintained components.
interfaces_current_justification: The project makes an earnest attempt to make sure that it doesn't use deprecated or obsolete functions and APIs.
regression_tests_added50_justification: The project earnestly tries to ensure that tests are added for all bugs that are fixed.  https://github.com/spiffe/spire/tree/master/test
implement_secure_design_justification: The project strives to implement secure design principles.
input_validation_justification: The project check all inputs from potentially untrusted sources to ensure they are valid,
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The project supports multiple cryptographic algorithms, where applicable.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: The project supports the storage of private cryptographic keys

name: dbparser
description: Source code for the R package, "dbparser" (i.e. DrugBank Parser)
description_good_justification:
The main purpose of the dbparser package is to parse the DrugBank database which is downloadable in XML format from this link. The parsed data can then be explored and analyzed as desired by the user. The dbparser package further provides the facility of saving the parsed data into a given database.
https://dainanahan.github.io/dbparser/index.html

name: Newsboat
description: An RSS/Atom feed reader for text terminals
description_good_justification: The first paragraph at https://newsboat.org/ says: "Newsboat is an RSS/Atom feed reader for the text console. It’s an actively maintained fork of Newsbeuter."
interact_justification: https://newsboat.org/ has links all the releases (clearly marking the most recent one), and also lists where to find our issue tracker, our mailing list, and our Git repository.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: "Development" section of our readme mentions our coding guide: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat#development We currently don't have any more formally written policies.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Links to documentation are at https://newsboat.org, the docs are also in the repository under "doc" directory.
documentation_interface_justification: `newsboat --help` explains command-line options. The program itself has a built-in dialog that explains what different keys do; the help dialog can be invoked with "?" key, which is mentioned at every screen. Man-pages mention all the settings available, partially duplicating the HTML documentation.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The repository is our primary means of collaboration, so commits are small(-ish); we sometimes squash small features into a single commit, but never a whole release.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Newsboat releases are identified through signed Git tags: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/releases
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Newsboat fixed two vulnerabilities that its parent project had, and identified them in the CHANGELOG: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#fixed-14
report_process_justification: Bug reports are welcome at https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/issues. We provide a template to help users gather all the necessary information: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/1a71f953905976d50ba816967864eb52080e092c/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE
report_responses_justification: Newsboat's maintainer, Alexander Batischev, triages new issues within a week of their submission. All issues get labels (bug/enhancement/meta etc.), I try to reproduce them with latest version from Git (and, failing that, with reporter's version), and ask for additional details if I can think of something that can help understand and fix the issue.
enhancement_responses_justification: The process is the same as with bug reports.
report_archive_justification: The whole archive is searchable on GitHub: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/issues
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: https://newsboat.org/ says: "If you have found a security vulnerability, **please email security@newsboat.org**, and use the aforementioned PGP key if at all possible."
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: https://newsboat.org/ says: "If you have found a security vulnerability, please email security@newsboat.org, and **use the aforementioned PGP key if at all possible**."
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: As of 2021-10-16, there are no known vulnerabilities in Newsboat.
build_floss_tools_justification: All the required libraries, compilers, and other tools are free software or open source: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/tree/00a7c26d47ea83408f6b69c6a968a2c36d2d6cc9#dependencies
test_justification: The test suite is located under "tests" directory. Rust code includes a copy, split between "rust/libnewsboat/tests", "rust/libnewsboat/proptest-regressions", doctests inside documentation, and `tests` modules inside the source.
test_invocation_justification: As of Newsboat 2.22 (December 21st, 2020) there is a Make target with a commonly-used name `check`. It invokes C++ and Rust test suites in sequence, failing when one of the suites fail.
test_policy_justification: Newsboat's maintainer, Alexander Batischev, asks people to add tests in their pull requests if the modified module already have tests, or if the module is otherwise obviously testeable. We still skip this requirement for modules that we haven't found a way to test yet, like UI.
tests_are_added_justification:
Here are a few recent PRs that added functionality to testeable modules:
https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/pull/543
https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/pull/584
https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/pull/590
https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/pull/653
https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/pull/658
tests_documented_added_justification: We always ask for tests to be added if the subsystem already has some.
warnings_justification:
Our C++ code is compiled with `-Wall -Wextra -Wunreachable-code`: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/00a7c26d47ea83408f6b69c6a968a2c36d2d6cc9/Makefile#L19

Our Rust code is compiled with default settings, which we believe are strict enough.
warnings_fixed_justification:
Our C++ code is compiled with `-Werror`: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/00a7c26d47ea83408f6b69c6a968a2c36d2d6cc9/Makefile#L19 We compile the code on multiple platforms with different versions of GCC and Clang, and fix all warnings that pop up.

Our Rust code is compiled with default settings, but on CI, we turn warnings into errors: see `-D warnings` in https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/1a71f953905976d50ba816967864eb52080e092c/.cirrus.yml. We then fix all warnings that pop up.
warnings_strict_justification: This is met by `-Werror` for C++ code https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/00a7c26d47ea83408f6b69c6a968a2c36d2d6cc9/Makefile#L19 and `-D warnings` for Rust code https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/1a71f953905976d50ba816967864eb52080e092c/.cirrus.yml.
crypto_published_justification: This isn't applicable since Newsboat doesn't implement and doesn't directly control what cryptography is used (e.g. client and server are free to negotiate any algorithm during HTTPS handshake, Newsboat has no say in that).
crypto_call_justification: Newsboat uses cryptography as part of HTTPS, and through programs that users choose to run (e.g. with `theoldreader-passwordeval` setting). Newsboat does not implement its own cryptography; it relies on Curl (which in turn relies on any of OpenSSL, LibreSSL, or some other backend) and programs chosen by the user (e.g. GPG).
crypto_floss_justification: Newsboat only requires Curl, which needs an SSL library. There are at least OpenSSL and GnuTLS that are FLOSS.
crypto_keylength_justification: This isn't applicable since Newsboat doesn't implement and doesn't directly control what cryptography is used (e.g. client and server are free to negotiate any algorithm during HTTPS handshake, Newsboat has no say in that).
crypto_working_justification: This isn't applicable since Newsboat doesn't implement and doesn't directly control what cryptography is used (e.g. client and server are free to negotiate any algorithm during HTTPS handshake, Newsboat has no say in that).
crypto_pfs_justification: This isn't applicable since Newsboat doesn't implement and doesn't directly control what cryptography is used (e.g. client and server are free to negotiate any algorithm during HTTPS handshake, Newsboat has no say in that).
crypto_password_storage_justification: Newsboat doesn't provide authentication to external users.
crypto_random_justification: Newsboat uses cryptography as part of HTTPS, and through programs that users choose to run (e.g. with `theoldreader-passwordeval` setting). Newsboat does not implement its own cryptography; it relies on Curl (which in turn relies on any of OpenSSL, LibreSSL, or some other backend) and programs chosen by the user (e.g. GPG).
delivery_mitm_justification: The releases are distributed from newsboat.org over HTTPS (enforced by HTTP Strict Transport Security), and are signed with a PGP key available over HTTPS from newsboat.org and also from the public keyserver network.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Release signatures are retrieved from newsboat.org over HTTPS, enforced by HTTP Strict Transport Security.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There are no publicly known vulnerabilities in Newsboat proper. All the publicly known vulnerabilities of the parent project, Newsbeuter, have been fixed; grep for "CVE" in the CHANGELOG: https://github.com/newsboat/newsboat/blob/00a7c26d47ea83408f6b69c6a968a2c36d2d6cc9/CHANGELOG.md
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: The last two vulnerabilities to parent project (which are fixed in Newsboat) have been privately disclosed, so it's not possible for me to prove that the fixes were produced rapidly. Take my (Alexander Batischev's) word that they were.
static_analysis_justification:
Newsboat's maintainer, Alexander Batischev, manually runs cppcheck every 30 days, i.e. three times per release. The check is not automated because of parse errors (as cppcheck doesn't fully support C++11).

Rust code is not checked (although C++ code that's auto-generated by Rust code *is* checked).

This could certainly be improved.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Static analysis haven't discovered any such vulnerabilities yet, so we don't have a history of fixing them timely.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: This isn't applicable since Newsboat doesn't implement and doesn't directly control what cryptography is used (e.g. client and server are free to negotiate any algorithm during HTTPS handshake, Newsboat has no say in that).
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: All the pull requests and merge commits are checked with Travis CI and Cirrus CI, which build the code on multitude of platforms using different compilers, and run tests on all of them.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: The documentation is only available in English. All discussions (on GitHub, IRC and the mailing list) are in English.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: FireO
description: A modern and simplest convenient ORM package in Python. FireO is specifically designed for the Google's Firestore
description_good_justification:
Previously there is library by Google called NDB python which is ORM model for Google Datastore. But recently Google announce Firestore is a next generation of Google datastore and they remove many Datastore drawbacks in Firestore. It create a problem for those users how are using Object-Relational Mapping they are not able to move on Firestore because NDB not support the Firestore. Here FireO comes into play. FireO is ORM package for Google Firestore Datastore mode and Firestore native mode. 

You can learn more about how you can use FireO. https://octabyte.io/FireO/

And some other common ways to check the doc string in python

1 - Pylint

You can search more on Google

name: Project Horizon
description: Next-generation installation system for the Adélie Linux distribution
contribution_justification: Merge requests or emailed patches: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst
contribution_requirements_justification: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst links to our Code Style Guide at https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/devel/STYLE.rst
license_location_justification:
https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/LICENSE
https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/LICENSE-code
https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/LICENSE-doc
floss_license_justification: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/LICENSE
documentation_basics_justification: https://horizon.adelielinux.org/
repo_public_justification: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon.git
repo_distributed_justification: Git is used for the source code repository: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon.git
version_unique_justification: Versions are bumped for user-facing releases using the VERSION parameter of CMake, as seen at https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt
release_notes_justification:
https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/0.2.0/CHANGELOG.rst is a ChangeLog file that is distributed with the source code.

https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/-/releases contains the ChangeLog notes for each version at the point where users would download the source code.
release_notes_vulns_justification: No known vulnerabilities have yet been reported.
report_archive_justification:
All issues, including open and closed ones, are at: https://bts.adelielinux.org/buglist.cgi?product=Horizon
The mailing list is archived at https://lists.adelielinux.org/hyperkitty/list/horizon@lists.adelielinux.org/ with a backup at https://www.mail-archive.com/horizon@lists.adelielinux.org/
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Vulnerabilities should be reported to the same BTS as other issues: https://bts.adelielinux.org/enter_bug.cgi?product=Horizon
build_justification: CMake is used, with full instructions found in the README.
build_common_tools_justification: CMake is the only build system, which can generate Makefiles, Ninja build files, among other common systems.
test_justification: The test suite is written in RSpec using the Aruba gem.  This allows us to write tests quickly that test the output of our CLI tools.
test_invocation_justification: Our tests are invoked via CTest.  https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/tools/hscript-validate/CMakeLists.txt
test_most_justification: Code coverage is over 90%, and monitored regularly.  https://horizon.adelielinux.org/coverage/
tests_are_added_justification: Every feature commit has corresponding test additions.
warnings_justification:
Using -Wall -Wextra -Werror since 686e0a9: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L17

CppCheck is used via Codacy: https://app.codacy.com/manual/awilfox/horizon/dashboard
warnings_fixed_justification: -Werror forces us to address every warning: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L17
crypto_published_justification: Since the installer sets passwords, it must use crypt(3).  It uses the SHA-512 and Blowfish algorithms only.
crypto_call_justification: TLS is used only via cURL, and crypt(3) relies on libc.
crypto_keylength_justification: Algorithms are not implemented within the software, and key sizes are not configurable in the libraries that the software uses.
delivery_mitm_justification: Horizon is only distributed via GitLab (which uses HTTPS) or on the Adélie installation CD images (which are cryptographically signed).
static_analysis_justification: Clang scan-build is run before release.  CppCheck is run per-commit via Codacy https://app.codacy.com/manual/awilfox/horizon/dashboard
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: CppCheck includes checks to ensure proper API usage.  It additionally ensures non-usage of known unsafe APIs (like gets).
static_analysis_often_justification: CppCheck is run per-commit via Codacy https://app.codacy.com/manual/awilfox/horizon/dashboard
dynamic_analysis_justification: Test suite includes 85% coverage and is run on every commit: https://horizon.adelielinux.org/coverage/
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Valgrind is run per-commit as part of CI: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/pipelines
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: GitLab CI runs on every commit, running the tests and additionally running basic functionality through Valgrind ensuring no memory errors nor leaks.  https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/pipelines
discussion_justification:
Mailing list: https://lists.adelielinux.org/postorius/lists/horizon.lists.adelielinux.org/
Issues: https://bts.adelielinux.org/buglist.cgi?product=Horizon&resolution=---
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Sample passphrases are clearly marked as samples and users are admonished not to use them.  See i.e. https://horizon.adelielinux.org/script/keys.html#rootpw
hardening_justification: Stack protector is on by default in Adélie Linux.  We additionally have many warning flags enabled and marked -Werror.
crypto_used_network_justification: Signing keys are only fetchable via HTTPS.  Repositories, user avatars, and HorizonScript files prefer HTTPS but support HTTP if the user explicitly requests them.
crypto_tls12_justification: TLS 1.2 should be supported by any cURL build with TLS support that would be used with Horizon.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: ibcurl performs peer SSL certificate verification by default: https://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: Certificate verification is performed during negotiation, before any HTTP headers are sent to the remote system.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: The system *is* an installation system.  CMake-generated Makefiles do support DESTDIR.
governance_justification: As part of the Adélie Linux project, Project Horizon is governed by the Adélie Linux Organisation Charter: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/docs/blob/master/src/charters/0001-org.rst
roles_responsibilities_justification: The README contains key contributors and their roles.  https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon
access_continuity_justification: Project Horizon inherits our geographically-diverse Platform Group leadership (as shown at https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/-/project_members and others) which ensures continuation of the project including issue maintenance, merge requests, and releases.
documentation_roadmap_justification: The Scope section of our Project Vision document ( https://horizon.adelielinux.org/vision/scope.html ) contains a roadmap of desired features for future releases.
documentation_current_justification: Documentation is kept in the same repository as the code.  The documentation is rebuilt on every commit and immediately live on https://horizon.adelielinux.org/.
documentation_achievements_justification: Our README ( https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/README.rst ) contains all of our earned badges.
internationalization_justification: The Horizon UI is written in Qt 5.  Translation support is enabled for all user-facing strings.
sites_password_security_justification: The Web site and repository are run on a self-hosted GitLab with proper access controls in place.
maintenance_or_update_justification: We have not yet released a second version of Horizon.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: No vulnerabilities have ever been reported for Project Horizon.
build_standard_variables_justification: Horizon is built with standard CMake.  These variables are tested regularly via our Clang scan-build tests.
build_preserve_debug_justification: CMake has Debug and RelWithDebugInfo build types to preserve debugging information.
build_non_recursive_justification: CMake generates the Makefiles (or Ninja build files, or others), keeping them updated as the structure of the project changes.
installation_standard_variables_justific: The system *is* an installation system.  CMake-generated Makefiles do support DESTDIR.
installation_development_quick_justifica: The Runtime Environment requires no external dependencies.  Since the Installation Environment is only meant to be used from Adélie Linux, it is assumed that `abuild deps` from the Horizon build recipe in our packages repository is sufficient for this, as it will install all the build dependencies for the Horizon Installation Environment.
external_dependencies_justification:
On systems that support C++17, there are no external dependencies for the Runtime Environment.

The Installation Environment dependencies are listed in the CMakeLists.txt file: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L56 using standard PkgConfig files.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: All external dependencies except CLIPP are provided by the system.  No other vendored code exists.
interfaces_current_justification: All APIs used in the Installation Environment are current and non-deprecated.  All APIs used in the Runtime Environment are part of C++14 and are not known to be obsolete or impending deprecation.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Test suite is run on every commit: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/pipelines
regression_tests_added50_justification: No bugs have been filed yet.  Regression tests are recommended in the contribution guide: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst
test_statement_coverage80_justification: We use LCOV ( http://ltp.sourceforge.net/coverage/lcov.php ) for coverage reports.  At the time of this writing, we have 83% coverage: https://horizon.adelielinux.org/coverage/
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is contained in our Contribution Guide: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst
input_validation_justification: Horizon's parser is strict and heavily tested.  We have achieved 100% test coverage in the parsing module.  All inputs are fully sanitised and errors are returned if the values are not within parameters.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: cURL is used to connect to HTTPS, so it is up to the distributor of the cURL library to ensure this is met.  The Adélie Linux build utilises OpenSSL and is fully configurable in this manner.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: While account passwords must be included in the HorizonScript, LUKS passphrases do not have to be - the user can be prompted for them instead.
signed_releases_justification: Git tags are cryptographically signed.  Release tarballs have GPG signatures from our development team.  See https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/-/releases for example.
version_tags_signed_justification: All Git tags are cryptographically signed: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/horizon/-/tags
copyright_per_file_justification:
All C++ source files contain the following comment header:

/*
 * FILENAME - Brief description of file
 * Component name
 * Project Horizon
 *
 * Copyright (c) YEAR Adélie Linux and contributors.  All rights reserved.
 * This code is licensed under the AGPL 3.0 license, as noted in the
 * LICENSE-code file in the root directory of this repository.
 *
 * SPDX-License-Identifier: AGPL-3.0-only
 */
license_per_file_justification: All source files contain the comment "SPDX-License-Identifier: AGPL-3.0-only".
require_2FA_justification: 2FA is required in our GitLab group.
secure_2FA_justification: The GitLab 2FA uses Authy-style authentication or U2F, not SMS.
test_statement_coverage90_justification: Test suite has 97% statement coverage at the time of this writing.
test_branch_coverage80_justification: Unfortunately, gcov and LCOV have a *lot* of false negatives in C++ code – internal STL function branches are counted in addition to our code.  We still managed almost 60% branch coverage, even including STL functions, when we tried to run this report.  We continue to watch this space for further development and hope to have a branch coverage solution that focuses only on our code.

name: Hyperledger Quilt
description: Hyperledger Quilt - An implementation of the Interledger Protocol
description_good_justification: The project's README provides a good explanation of Interledger (with links) and what Quilt is trying to accomplish. Also, the Hyperledger wiki does the same (see https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/quilt/Hyperledger+Quilt).
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: See here (https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#structure-and-conventions) as well as coding-style (enforced by Checkstyle automated checks during PR submission): https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-style
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Documentation is part of our README, which primarily begins here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-style

Also, we have an `examples` folder which details how to use the library. See here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/tree/master/examples-parent
documentation_interface_justification:
See extensive Javadoc for each module, published to Maven Central. These coordinates and actual javadoc are documented on our README here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt#modules

For example, see Javadoc for ilp-core here: https://www.javadoc.io/doc/org.interledger/ilp-core/1.0.1/index.html
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
All changes are merged via github PRs for collaborative review. They are labeled with a version-label to identify which version of the library the issue was fixed in, or a PR was targeted at. See here for an example of our changelog for `v1.0.0` (https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/milestone/2?closed=1) and for our `v1.0.1` patch-release (https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/milestone/3?closed=1)

Releases are tracked here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/releases
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: All releases are identified via Git tags. See here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/tags
release_notes_justification: Release notes are added to each markdown file in Github. See the section "CHANGELOG" in each release. E.g., https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/releases
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no known vulnerabilities in the project, although a variety of automated static analysis tools are employed such as LGTM (https://lgtm.com/projects/g/hyperledger/quilt/alerts/) and Github's automatic dependency analyzer (https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/configuring-automated-security-fixes). Additionally, the project's test-coverage is automatically tracked and graded on every commit. See https://codecov.io/gh/hyperledger/quilt
report_process_justification: This is in our project's README and uses Github issues to track all bugs: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/issues
report_responses_justification: See labels in our issue tracker here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/labels
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Vulnerabilities in the protocol are handled via existing interledger.org processes. Vulnerabilities in Quilt can be publicly published via our issue tracker: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/issues
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There have been no vulnerabilities reported.
test_justification:
The project has extensive unit and integration test coverage that is run on every build (branch and master) using CircleCI: https://circleci.com/gh/hyperledger/quilt

The project also has code-coverage reporting that is updated on every build (all branches and master): https://codecov.io/gh/hyperledger/quilt
test_invocation_justification: All tests can be run using Maven via the following command: `mvn clean install`.
test_most_justification: Code coverage is generated using the Jacoco maven plugin which runs automatically as part of each build.
tests_are_added_justification: See any PR merging into master -- all tests must pass on 7 different versions of Java. E.g., https://circleci.com/workflow-run/b99a21da-8a27-4c7a-b46a-2c6c9522733d
warnings_justification: The project uses Checkstyle and LGTM.com.
warnings_strict_justification: Any warnings produced by the library are logged to standard logging syncs enabled via SLF4j.
know_secure_design_justification: The lead project maintainer has ~20 years of Java software engineering experience. The other two primary maintainers have over 13 years experience each.
know_common_errors_justification: The lead project maintainer has ~20 years of Java software engineering experience. The other two primary maintainers have over 13 years experience each.
crypto_published_justification: Where Quilt uses cryptography, signing, hashing, etc, it uses either standard JVM primitives or primitives found in Google's Guava library (https://github.com/google/guava), which is extensively tested and widely deployed (currently > 34k stars on Github).
crypto_working_justification:
All encryption/decryption and hashing algorithms implemented in Quilt are specified by Interledger RFCs, which conform to the requirements above (e.g., the protocols stipulate usage of the `SHA-256` algorithm for hashing and also specify limited symmetric encryption usage using AES with GCM/NoPadding using standard NIST recommended Nonce and IV lengths per https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-38d.pdf. 

The library implements all hashing primitives using Google's Guava library. All encryption implementations are provided by the standard JDK.
crypto_pfs_justification: Key agreement protocol encryption is not part of Quilt.
crypto_random_justification: All random numbers are produced via standard JVM mechanisms like SecureRandom, which is a cryptographically strong random number generator (RNG) that  minimally complies with the statistical random number generator tests specified in FIPS 140-2, Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules, section 4.9.1.
delivery_mitm_justification: All software releases are performed via Sonatype and then mirrored to Maven Central. All artifacts are signed. For example, see https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/interledger/ilp-core/1.0.1/
delivery_unsigned_justification: All software releases are performed via Sonatype and then mirrored to Maven Central. All artifacts are signed. For example, see https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/interledger/ilp-core/1.0.1/
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The project employs both https://lgtm.com/projects/g/hyperledger/quilt/alerts/?mode=list and https://app.codacy.com/manual/xpring/quilt/dashboard for static code analysis.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: There are various run-time assertions in the code to prevent, e.g., NullPointers as well as invariants that should not be met.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
crypto_used_network_justification: Any network communications use TLS 1.2 or above.
crypto_tls12_justification: Any network communications use TLS 1.2 or above.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: TLS Certificate validation is enabled by default in all HTTP clients used in Quilt, although a developer may disable this functionality using standard configuration settings outside of the control of Quilt developers since HTTP client libraries are implemented by a third party (see https://square.github.io/okhttp/)
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: TLS Certificate validation is enabled by default in all HTTP clients used in Quilt, although a developer may disable this functionality using standard configuration settings outside of the control of Quilt developers since HTTP client libraries are implemented by a third party (see https://square.github.io/okhttp/)
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Quilt is a library and is not installed by itself. Usage instructions are provided in the project's README.
dco_justification: All commits to the repo have DCO sign-off. See section 13a of https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter
governance_justification: The project operates under the Hyperledger governance system. See All commits to the repo have DCO sign-off. See https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter
code_of_conduct_justification: The project operates under the Hyperledger governance system. See All commits to the repo have DCO sign-off. See https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter
bus_factor_justification: The project has three core maintainers. See committed PRs here: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed
internationalization_justification: The software doesn't generate text intended for end-users and doesn't sort human-readable text.
sites_password_security_justification: The project sites do not store passwords for this purpose.
maintenance_or_update_justification: All versions of the library are kept forever in Github in our releases section. They are also permanently accessible in Maven Central.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: The project uses Checkstyle to automatically enforce all code style rules on every build.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Quilt is a library and is not installed by itself. Usage instructions are provided in the project's README.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Quilt is a library and is not installed by itself. Usage instructions are provided in the project's README.
external_dependencies_justification: All dependencies are managed via Maven in this pom.xml file: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/pom.xml
updateable_reused_components_justificati: All dependencies are managed via Maven in this pom.xml file: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/pom.xml
interfaces_current_justification: All dependencies are managed via Maven in this pom.xml file: https://github.com/hyperledger/quilt/blob/master/pom.xml
automated_integration_testing_justificat: All tests are run on every build in the Quilt project.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: All tests are run on every build in the Quilt project. Codecov coverage reporting requires 80% overall code coverage in the project: https://codecov.io/gh/hyperledger/quilt
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The cryptographic algorithms implemented in Quilt are specified via Interledger protocol RFC. If these primitives become broken or unreliable, the RFCs will be updated which will trigger updates to Quilt.
